title: CFL close to a solution on drug testing | PAUL FRIESEN | Football Tor
text:
The CFL with a strong, working drug policy and a sold-out Winnipeg Grey Cup?
Both, believe it or not, appear sure things.
Let’s start with the drug policy.
It was back on July 2 when CFL commissioner Jeffrey Orridge made his first trip to Winnipeg, looked me in the eye and said he’d have the league’s mess of a program fixed within weeks, “at most.”
More than three months later, we’re still waiting. There’s still no policy in place and players still aren’t being tested.
But there’s hope on the horizon.
Because the last thing Orridge wants to do is show up in Winnipeg again for the 103rd Grey Cup, less than seven weeks away, with this embarrassment still hanging over his first season in office.
“We’re getting close,” Paulo Senra, CFL director of communications, told the Winnipeg Sun, Tuesday. “There’s an improved and revised proposal on the table right now.”
It still needs final agreement, though. And three signatures.
And get this: the third could come from the Canadian Centre for Ethics in Sport, the same organization Orridge slammed the door on earlier this season.
You may recall how Orridge reacted to criticism from the CCES and the head of the Quebec lab it contracted by shutting down the program altogether, June 11.
Well, it seems the commish may have come to his senses and realized the CCES was the best thing going for the toothless policy he inherited.
Because word is the CCES is back at the table, although nobody was confirming as much, Tuesday.
Notable: they weren’t denying it, either.
“I’m not able to comment on what you’re hearing,” CCES president/CEO Paul Melia said, via e-mail.
If the CCES is back as a partner, the league stands a good chance of getting this right. Finally.
The organization and the head of its lab, Dr. Christiane Ayotte, have long tried to get the CFL to get tougher on drug cheats.
Its policy was the weakest in pro sports, with no sanction for first-time offenders and no independent management of its test results.
When graduating Canadian university players began taking advantage of it — five of them failed drug tests at the pre-draft combine last spring, knowing they’d face no penalties as pros — the alarm bells went off.
Everybody heard them — except for Orridge and players association boss Scott Flory, apparently.
Leading player agent Darren Gill and University of Manitoba Bisons head coach Brian Dobie called for the league to act, while Ayotte said her lab could no longer in good conscience do the league’s testing.
Even the head of the World Anti-Doping Agency called the league on the carpet.
So the CFL took its ball and went south, trying to find another agency and lab to administer the program, at the same time promising to improve it.
When the only other two WADA-approved labs in North America turned the CFL down, it had little choice but to consider re-binding the ties it cut with the CCES.
We’ll see what they come up with.
“I’ve got my fingers crossed,” Dobie said, Tuesday, calling the CFL the “final frontier” in the fight against performance-enhancing drugs in football. “That’s the last thing missing.”
Which brings us to the Grey Cup, which had been missing a critical element just seven weeks ago: paying customers.
After being forced to reveal they’d downsized the capacity from 40,000 to 36,634, yet still had some 11,000 tickets to sell, the Winnipeg Blue Bombers have seen a surge in sales, relatively speaking.
A check with Ticketmaster showed just over 2,000 tickets remained as of mid-afternoon, Tuesday, all but ensuring the game will be a sellout.
Checking with the Bombers didn’t reveal any particular reason, just “increased demand and strong response from the business community of late,” read an e-mail from the communications department.
It’ll still be the smallest Grey Cup crowd in 17 years.
But at least the Bombers will be spared the embarrassment of having thousands of empty seats at a venue that was already downsized.
Now who says you never read positive news in this space?
